bibl.title: Despatch from Ezekiel E. Smith to George L. Rives, February 18, 1889
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 16
Consulate General, U. S. A. Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 18th, 1889
Mr. Ezekiel E. Smith To the Deartment of State.
SUBJECT:
Forms &c for Elmina.
ABSTRACT OF CONTENTS.
The Consular Agent at Elmina, GOld Coast COlony, wishes forms: 101,103, 117, 120, 130, also, an American flag or flag of the U.S.
Consulate General, U. S. A. Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 18th, 1889
Honorable G. L. Rives Assistant Secretary of State, Wasington, D. C.
Sir: I have the honor respectfully to forward, herewith, a communication from the U.S. consular Agent at Elmina, Gold Coast Colony, requesting supplies for his office.
I have them not on hand, in this Consulate General.
I am, sir, your obedient servant,
Ezekiel E. Smith U.S. Consul Gen'l
Inclosure, one.
1. Mer Eminsang to Mer Smith
Consulate of the United States, Elmina, Gold Coast Colony December 10th 1888
Ezekiel E. Smith Esqu: U.S. Minister Resident & Consul General Monrovia, Liberia
Sir: Your despatch no. 1 to hand in reply I have the honor to state that I am most in need for this Consulate the following Forms: No. 101 (the new form) & Nos: 103; 117; 120. 130.
I would feel much obliged if your Honor could supply me with the above. I should thank you also if you could supply this Consulate with an American Flag, which is very much needed.
I am, Sir, Your most obedient Servant.
G. E. Eminsang U.S. Consular Agent
